isis.stitle: Spanish - Guía para Localización de Fallas del Sistema Eléctrico - 3200, 4200, 4300, 4400, 7300, 7400, 7500, 8500, 8600 - STOPMASTER WEDGE TYPE BRAKE - SERVICE - AIR CHAMBER ASSEMBLY

step1.para: Block wheels to prevent vehicle from moving. Then cage the spring and disconnect brake lines. Be sure air is exhausted from parking brake system. Air chambers used are of the bottoming type. Bottoming air chambers have an identification tag fastened to the clamp ring bolt. Refer to , CAGING AND UNCAGING SPRING BRAKE.
If an adjusting type unit is used, carefully mark the position of the assembly on the first exposed thread of the housing tube with a scribe or punch to aid reassembly.
Using a drift or other blunt tool and hammer, loosen the collet (lock) nut ( Figure 19).

With welded-on spiders and mounted open end brakes, the complete actuation system can be removed at this time by removing four (4) spider to plunger housing capscrews. The hub and drum assembly as well as the dust shield must be removed before the actuation system is removed ( Figure 20).
Unscrew the air chamber from the plunger housing ( Figure 21). At this time, remove and inspect the wedge assembly. Service if necessary.
Spread the clamp ring. Hold the diaphragm on the non-pressure half and remove the pressure half or spring brake chamber ( Figure 10).
Carefully remove the diaphragm ( Figure 22) while holding diaphragm plate against the wedge rod. This will prevent the wedge assembly from coming out of engagement with the plungers.

figure.caption: Figure 22. Exploded View of Brake Chamber Assembly

step1.para: If wedge assembly backs out of plunger anytime during this entire procedure, remove non-pressure housing from brake to replace diaphragm.

Continue to hold plate and inspect boot ( Figure 22). If boot is torn or not attached to housing, strip old boot free from housing and carefully remove plate assembly off wedge rod and out of non-pressure housing tube. (Boot and wedge guide will remain on plate push rod.)
Remove wedge guide and old boot from push rod. Inspect guide for wear and replace if necessary.
Install new boot on diaphragm plate push rod and press wedge guide all the way onto end of push rod.
Clean non-pressure housing with cement thinner or similar material in area where boot is to be cemented.
Apply cement to housing around tube end. Position the plate push rod assembly into tube. Carefully engage wedge rod so as to not pull it out of plungers.
While holding plate against wedge, press boot into position for cementing.
Install new diaphragm over plate and onto non-pressure housing while pushing plate against wedge. Assemble pressure half and clamp ring in reverse manner of disassembly.
Connect air lines to proper chamber and spring brake ports. Make a full pressure brake application and check for air leaks. Road test for brake performance.
